member.name: T:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ASynchronousCommsUser
member.summary: This is the main "comms user" class used to make asynchronous requests to a device.
member.remarks:
Most methods in this class work asynchronously - i.e. you make a request such as and providing that method returns a value of you then just wait for the event to fire which will contain the response from the device or it will indicate a timeout condition.
It is important to note that only one request can be made at a time so always wait for the response before making any further requests.

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ICommsUser.Go(ControlTechniques.CommsServer.Protocol)
member.summary: Switches the user on to the specified protocol. If a protocol has been previously set the user object will relinquish its use of the port.

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ICommsUser.Stop
member.summary: Turn the user off and release the port.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ICommsUser.MaxTransmitBufferSizeBytes
member.summary: Gets/sets the maximum number of bytes a client can place into a file write or tunneled frame (for example). This will not include message header size.
member.remarks: Note that for file write operations this value will be ignored and instead the target device will be queried for its buffer size at the start of the write process, though this can be suppressed by specifying the flag in or (in which case this value will apply). The actual maximum number of bytes transmitted may be less than this value as it will be aligned to a 32-bit boundary. So if this property value is set to 330 the actual number of bytes will actually be 328.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ICommsUser.TheProtocol
member.summary: Returns the protocol currently in use by the user. null may be returned if the user has not called Go (or has since called Stop).

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ICommsUser.IsActive
member.summary: Returns whether the user is active, i.e. has been called.

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ASynchronousCommsUser.ReadWithType(ControlTechniques.CommsServer.CommsAddress,ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPReadWithTypeRequest)
member.summary: Read parameter values with type information from the target.
member.remarks:
The event will return an object of type .
Most devices support reading at least 10 parameters in one request. For example, the Unidrive M RTU interface will only allow a maximum of 10 whereas the Ethernet interface will do more. For maximum compatibility it is recommended you stick to no more than 10.
If you wish to continually read parameters and get notifed when the value or status changes use .

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ASynchronousCommsUser.FileExists(ControlTechniques.CommsServer.CommsAddress,ControlTechniques.CommsServer.FileExistsRequest)
member.summary: Check if the specified target file exists.
member.remarks: The existence check can be done two ways: (1) By attempting to open the file, or (2) issuing a ECMP FileExists command. By default method 1 is used since many devices do not support FileExists command and so this method is more compatbile. However you can force method 2 to be used instead by specifying =true.
member.param: The address of the target device holding the file
The request containing the target file name to check

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ASynchronousCommsUser.FileInfo(ControlTechniques.CommsServer.CommsAddress,ControlTechniques.CommsServer.FileInfoRequest)
member.summary: Request information about a file such as its file length.
member.remarks: Not all tagets will support this command, and the which attributes are supported is also target and file location dependant. Certain targets may also impose a limit on how many attributes may be requested in one request.
member.param: The address of the target device holding the file
The request containing the target file name and the attributes to get.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ASynchronousCommsUser.MaxTransmitBufferSizeBytes
member.summary: Sets/gets the maximum number of bytes sent in a file transfer or tunneled frame.
member.remarks:
An out-of-range value will be ignored (range 16-1000).
The default value should be suitable in most cases. The value can be set to the obtained from the target.
Note that file transfer (using and ) automatically query the target device for its buffer size and will use that value for the file transfer. To force the value of this property to be used instead specify the flag in the request.

member.summary: If this is set then the ECMP FileExists command will be used instead of the more compatible (and default) FileOpen method.
member.remarks: Using FileExists is more efficient but many targets do not support it. Use for the command with the code 0x2A to check if a target supports it.

member.name: F:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.FileWriteOptions.DisableAutoBufferSize
member.summary: Specify this flag to suppress automatic buffer size calculation. Without this set the target device will be queried for how much data it can accept per packet when the file transfer is started and this will be used during the write, overriding the default value given by . If you wish to specify an exact buffer size to use instead then set this flag and set the appropriate buffer size via .

member.name: T:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.Internal.ByteArrayMerger
member.summary: This is a utility class that holds a hash of byte array references and allows them to be appended together to form one single byte array.
member.remarks:
This hold references to the byte arrays, so the content of the arrays can still be altered after adding them to this object.
The order of the data in the merged byte array is dependent upon the order the byte arrays were added to the dictionary.

This regex will accept "1.2.3.4.5" is accepted (5 being the slot number) so the code needs to trap for that.

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.BlockingCommsUser.FileExists(ControlTechniques.CommsServer.CommsAddress,ControlTechniques.CommsServer.FileExistsRequest,ControlTechniques.CommsServer.FileExistsResponse@)
member.summary: Check if the specified target file exists.
member.remarks: The existence check can be done two ways: (1) By attempting to open the file, or (2) issuing a ECMP FileExists command. By default method 1 is used since many devices do not support FileExists command and so this method is more compatbile. However you can force method 2 to be used instead by specifying =true.
member.param: The address of the target device holding the file
The request containing the target file name to check

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.BlockingCommsUser.FileInfo(ControlTechniques.CommsServer.CommsAddress,ControlTechniques.CommsServer.FileInfoRequest,ControlTechniques.CommsServer.FileInfoResponse@)
member.summary: Request information about a file such as its file length.
member.remarks: Not all tagets will support this command, and the which attributes are supported is also target and file location dependant. Certain targets may also impose a limit on how many attributes may be requested in one request.
member.param: The address of the target device holding the file
The request containing the target file name and the attributes to get.

member.summary: The progress of the current file transfer action

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.BlockingCommsUser.MaxTransmitBufferSizeBytes
member.summary: Sets/gets the maximum number of bytes sent in a file transfer or tunneled frame.
member.remarks:
An out-of-range value will be ignored (range 16-1000).
The default value should be suitable in most cases. The value can be set to the obtained from the target.
Note that file transfer (using and ) automatically query the target device for its buffer size and will use that value for the file transfer. To force the value of this property to be used instead specify the flag in the request.

member.name: T:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.DiscoveredUnconfiguredNode
member.summary: Represents a Ethernet node that has been discovered but it may not be possible to communicate to it possibly due to it not being accessible via its IP address. This could mean that it is unconfigured. The node will have responded to a discovery request on the local subnet so usually it should also respond to normal eCMP queries too.

member.name: T:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.INode
member.summary: Interface to hold values for and of a node

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.INode.Address
member.summary: The address to be used to communicate with the node.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.INode.InterfaceAddress
member.summary: The address of the Ethernet port on the device if it has one. Will be null if no Ethernet interface is available. Note that this address will be different from if the node can be reached via different routes or protocols.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.INode.Protocol
member.summary: The protocol on which the node was discovered.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.IUnconfiguredNode.TypeName
member.summary: Type name as returned from the discovery protocol.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.IUnconfiguredNode.Name
member.summary: The user defined name for the node.

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.DiscoveredUnconfiguredNode.#ctor(CTCOMMSSERVERLib.IUnconfiguredNode)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.DiscoveredUnconfiguredNode.Set(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Writes various configuration parameters to the device by issuing a Discovery Protocol assign command.
member.remarks:
The following properties are set: - DHCPEnabled, IPAaddress, Gateway, Netmask.
The username and password may be required by some devices.
member.returns: true if device accepted request, false otherwise.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.DiscoveredUnconfiguredNode.TypeName
member.summary: Type name as returned from the discovery protocol.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.DiscoveredUnconfiguredNode.Name
member.summary: The user defined name for the node.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.DiscoveredUnconfiguredNode.Address
member.summary: Get/sets the comms address. When setting, ensure address is an IP address.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.DiscoveredUnconfiguredNode.InterfaceAddress
member.summary: The address of the Ethernet port on the device, which will be the same as .

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.DiscoveredUnconfiguredNode.Protocol
member.summary: The protocol on which the node was discovered.

member.summary: Construct with specified Cyclic Link Number

member.summary: Convert request into sequence of bytes ready for embedding into an eCMP request

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.Mode
member.summary: Cyclic Link Mode for this request

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.Attributes
member.summary: List of cyclic link attributes

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.MotionEngineCycleOffset
member.summary: The offset in nanoseconds from the start of the motion cycle that data should be processed.
member.remarks: This is the point received data should be written and transmitted data should be sampled. If not specified default value is 0. null if not present in the response data.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.RxTimeoutHandler
member.summary: Rx Timeout Handler. Defines what action should be taken when data fails to be received.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.RxLateDataHandler
member.summary: Rx Late Data Handler. Defines what action should be taken when data is received late (data was received after it should have been processed).

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.TransportAddress
member.summary: Transport Address. This is the address of the link source (for an RX link) or destination (for a TX link).

members.member:
Maximum number of mappings.
Can only be set during link creation. Not used when using the newer cyclic link interface (see , , ).
\deprecated This attribute is obsolete and should not be used.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.MappingItems
member.summary: A mapping item describes the source / destination of data to be mapped in to the process image.

members.member:
Whether the link is persistent (true) or volatile (false)
\deprecated This attribute is obsolete and should not be used.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.SamplePeriod
member.summary: The time between each sampling of cyclic data. For synchronised links this must be a multiple of all receiving nodes motion cycle periods

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.MotionEngineCycleDelay
member.summary: The offset from the start of the motion cycle the data was sampled in to the start of the motion cycle the receiving data must use the data

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.LinkStatus
member.summary: Status as defined by register 10.1. To clear status bits write to this register with corresponding bit set

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.LinkName
member.summary: ASCII name for the link. Maximum length of string is 32 ASCII characters.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkCreateRequest.LinkTag
member.summary: Tag used by configuration software to detect changes made to links once initialization of the device and therefore its stored configuration has completed. Value shall be non-zero set by configuration tool. Any further change shall set tag to zero. Tag value defaults to zero if not set.
member.remarks: This is different from the property as that is only on PC side and does not form part of the cyclic link message.

member.name: T:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkDeleteRequest
member.summary: Cyclic Link Delete Request
member.remarks: Delete the specified link configuration

member.summary: Cyclic Link Mode for this request

member.summary: A list of attributes that have been successfully set, or null if not valid for request.

member.summary: The current link state, or null
member.remarks: If not valid for this state or not present in the response data then this property will be null.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.LinkDirection
member.summary: Is this link configured for transmitting or receiving?
member.remarks: null if not present in the response data

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.Synchronised
member.summary: Is this link synchronised to the motion cycle?

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.MotionEngineCycleOffset
member.summary: The offset in nanoseconds from the start of the motion cycle that data should be processed.
member.remarks: This is the point received data should be written and transmitted data should be sampled. If not specified default value is 0. null if not present in the response data.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.SamplePeriod
member.summary: The time between each sampling of cyclic data. For synchronised links this must be a multiple of all receiving nodes motion cycle periods

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.MotionEngineCycleDelay
member.summary: The offset from the start of the motion cycle the data was sampled in to the start of the motion cycle the receiving data must use the data

member.summary: Only transmit data if it has changed

member.summary: Status of the link.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.LinkName
member.summary: Name of link for configuration software use.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.LinkTag
member.summary: Tag for configuration software use.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.StatusCounters
member.summary: Status counters for bits 1 to 31 defined by register 10.1. Counters will increment up to 65000; if a device does not support a counter then 65535 will be returned. Any counter can be cleared with a write of any value.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.GlobalLinkStatus
member.summary: Bitwise OR of all configured links LINK_STATUS (14) bits 1-31. Bit 0 is a bitwise AND of all bit 0 for all configured links. A 1 for bit 0 in the Global Link Status indicates all links are running. A write to this attribute of any value will clear the global link status AND ALL configured link status attributes (attribute LINK_STATUS (14)).

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.ResetLinkStatusCounters
member.summary: Any write to this attribute wshall cause all link status counters (attributes 18 to 48) to be cleared. A read shall always return 0.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.AppliedMecDelay
member.summary: TX ONLY - MEC Delay value applied to transmission timestamp accounting for any synchronised task advancements and offsets

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.SynchronousRxMecOffset
member.summary: A device may advance or retard the processing of synchornous recieve links. This attribute describes the magnitude in nanoseconds and direction (+ is advance, - is retard)

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.ECMPCyclicLinkResponse.SynchronousTxMecOffset
member.summary: A device may advance or retard the pro- cessing of synchornous transmit links. This attribute describes the magnitude in nanoseconds and direction (+ is advance, - is retard)

member.summary: Bitwise OR of all configured links LINK_STATUS (14) bits 1-31. Bit 0 is a bitwise AND of all bit 0 for all configured links. A 1 for bit 0 in the Global Link Status indicates all links are running. A write to this attribute of any value will clear the global link status AND ALL configured link status attributes (attribute LINK_STATUS (14)).

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.FileListRequest.DirectoryHash
member.summary: Optional directory hash to match against. If this is set and the target reports the same hash code then the file enumeration is stopped after the first message exchange with the target and the flag is set in the response. It is the responsibility of the client to cache the directory contents. This is an optimisation feature and should be left as null if not required.
member.remarks: Some targets may not support the hash.

member.summary: An event fired when a node has been discovered and all required information obtained, e.g. if a drive is discovered, this event will only get fired when all option information has been obtained and attached to the drive node object.
member.remarks: If a device is accessible via different addresses then this event will be raised for each address unless you set the . Duplicates are determined by comparing the serial number of the drive/base device.

member.summary: Configures Ethernet Node using Discovery Protocol. The node must be accessible via UDP.
member.remarks:
If this method returns without exception then a node has responded to the reconfiguration.
Note that it may take the node a few seconds to recofigure itself (especially if DHCP is enabled).
member.param: list of to use to configure the specified node. Specify null to issue request out on all appropriate interfaces.
Username. May be required by some node types (typically legacy such as SM-Ethernet).
Password - only relevant if Username set.
Whether to enable DHCP on the node or not
Group ID (used by legacy devices, set to 0 if not relevant)
Node ID (used by legacy devices, set to 0 if not relevant)
member.exception: If any of , , or are null

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.SmlCommsUser.NewSection
member.summary: Create a new section. After calling this method, all subsequent ECMP requests will be added to the new section.
member.returns: Status. A status of FAILED is returned if the maximum number of sections has been reached.

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.SmlCommsUser.ProcessResponse(System.Byte[],System.Collections.Generic.List{ControlTechniques.CommsServer.SmlSectionResponse}@)
member.summary: Parse SML response data. This must be a valid SML data stream containing only ECMP responses.
member.remarks:
This method will refer to cached request data so that the reponses include the original request, therefore for this to work you must first create the SML request using Write(), CyclicLink(), NewSection(), etc. then send the SML file to the target device, then use the same instance of this object to process the response. In between sending the request and getting the response no other request methods should be called.
You can call this method without having used the instance to create the request - in this case the responses will not have any reference to the request and it is left to the client to interpret the responses correctly.
If in the former case (where this instance is used to create the request) but the number of sections in the response from the target does not match the request, a warning result of will be returned however processing the responses will attempt to continue but there will be a possibility that the responses received won't correctly tie in with the requests, therefore the client should be cautious in using the results.
member.param: Full response data obtained from target device.
member.returns: Indication as to whether processing was ok.

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.SmlCommsUser.Transmit(ControlTechniques.CommsServer.CommsAddress,System.Int32)
member.summary:
This method is not yet implemented.
Transmit the SML file to the target device and (optionally) start a thread monitoring for a response file and process it. If a response is requested the ResponseAvailable event will be raised.
member.remarks: This method may only be used after a call to .
member.param: Address of device to send file to.
Time to wait for a response file from the target. Specify 0 to not wait for a response.

member.name: T:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.CRC32
member.summary:
Provides an implementation of CRC32 (32-bit CRC) as used in Ethernet, PKZip etc. This implementation is capable of providing a small footprint version, optimised for ROM and RAM size rather than speed, or a slightly larger footprint version optimised for speed. To optimise for speed define "OPTIMISE_FOR_SPEED" in file "crc32cfg.hpp".
Optimised for speed:
Code usage on SH2A: 88 bytes Const usage on SH2A: 1032 bytes Stack usage on SH2A: 12 bytes Time to CRC 1024 bytes: 360 us (370ns per byte) Time to CRC 32768 bytes: 12200 us (370ns per byte)
Not optimised for speed:
Code usage on SH2A: 156 bytes Const usage on SH2A: 8 bytes Stack usage on SH2A: 4 bytes Time to CRC 1024 bytes: 2250 us (2.2us per byte) Time to CRC 32768 bytes: 71800 us (2.2us per byte)
Timing tests conducted on UT70A, SH2A running at 57.4MHz code running from internal (single cycle) flash, CRCing data in internal flash, Stack in external RAM:

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.CRC32.Calculate(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,ControlTechniques.CommsServer.CRC32.T_CRC_DIRECTION)
member.summary: Calculate CRC of a data array.
member.param: Number of bytes in array over which to calculate the CRC.

member.summary: Calculate CRC of a data array.
member.param: Number of bytes in array over which to calculate the CRC.

member.summary: The time between each sampling of cyclic data.
member.remarks: For synchronised links this must be a multiple of all receiving nodes motion cycle periods.

member.summary: The offset from the start of the motion cycle the data was sampled in to the start of the motion cycle the receiving node must use the data.

member.summary: Base period of the Motion Engine Cycle in ns

member.name: F:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.T_CYCLIC_LINK_ATTRIBUTE.GLOBAL_LINK_STATUS
member.summary: Bitwise OR of all configured links LINK_STATUS (14) bits 1-31. Bit 0 is a bitwise AND of all bit 0 for all configured links. A 1 for bit 0 in the Global Link Status indicates all links are running. A write to this attribute of any value will clear the global link status AND ALL configured link status attributes (attribute LINK_STATUS (14)).

member.name: F:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.T_CYCLIC_LINK_ATTRIBUTE.RESET_LINK_STATUS_COUNTERS
member.summary: Any write to this attribute wshall cause all link status counters (attributes 18 to 48) to be cleared. A read shall always return 0.

member.name: T:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.PollingCommsUser
member.summary: Provides a "comms user" that requires you "poll" for responses.
member.remarks:
It is recommended to use which provides an event based system.
If you insist on using this class then remember to sleep / do events in your polling loop otherwise you risk your program becoming unresponsive and may even prevent comms response from being handled. Avoid using this class in a UI thread. The may be used as an alternative - that does the polling loop part but waits on a semaphore so releasing the thread.

member.name: M:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.PollingCommsUser.FileExists(ControlTechniques.CommsServer.CommsAddress,ControlTechniques.CommsServer.FileExistsRequest)
member.summary: Check if the specified target file exists.
member.remarks: The existence check can be done two ways: (1) By attempting to open the file, or (2) issuing a ECMP FileExists command. By default method 1 is used since many devices do not support FileExists command and so this method is more compatbile. However you can force method 2 to be used instead by specifying =true.
member.param: The address of the target device holding the file
The request containing the target file name to check

member.summary: Request information about a file such as its file length.
member.remarks: Not all tagets will support this command, and the which attributes are supported is also target and file location dependant. Certain targets may also impose a limit on how many attributes may be requested in one request.
member.param: The address of the target device holding the file
The request containing the target file name and the attributes to get.

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.PollingCommsUser.MaxTransmitBufferSizeBytes
member.summary: Sets/gets the maximum number of bytes sent in a file transfer or tunneled frame.
member.remarks:
An out-of-range value will be ignored (range 16-1000).
The default value should be suitable in most cases. The value can be set to the obtained from the target.
Note that file transfer (using and ) automatically query the target device for its buffer size and will use that value for the file transfer. To force the value of this property to be used instead specify the flag in the request.

member.name: T:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.TunnelFrameRequest
member.summary: A block of bytes to be transmitted to a device. The byte array can be of any size, the server will chunk it appropriately to get the entire block of data into the device.

member.summary: The bytes of data to tunnel to the target

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.TunnelFrameRequest.CheckOutput
member.summary: Set to true if the response generated by the tunnel target should be sent back to the request instigator

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.TunnelFrameRequest.IgnoreControlFlags
member.summary: If set to true the control flags for the request will be set to zero, this is to get around an issue with the drive firmware that will later be corrected

member.name: P:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.TunnelFrameRequest.OverridingTimeout
member.summary: An overriding timeout to use for this specific tunnel frame request. This should only be set for special transient situations where it is known a device may take longer to respond than normal. By default the is used.

member.name: T:ControlTechniques.CommsServer.TunnelFrameResponse
member.summary: A block of bytes received from a device. The byte array can be of any size, the server will chunk it appropriately to get the entire block of data out of the device.
